I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program, and 
(ii) proposed policy-based loans to the Republic of Uzbekistan for subprogram 1 of the Small and 
Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program. The report also describes proposed technical 
assistance (TA) for Support to Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program, and 
if the Board approves the proposed loans, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The proposed program will improve the enabling environment for small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs), increasing their resilience to future economic shocks and allowing them to 
become drivers of private sector-led, diversified economic growth with high-value-added job 
creation. The program is a systematic next step in the support of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for SMEs in Uzbekistan, which commenced in 1996 and has focused primarily on access 
to finance and improving the financial and technical capacity of participating financial institutions 
to  better  serve  micro  and  small  enterprises.  Cross-sector  reforms  under  the  program—
comprising  simplifying  and  streamlining  the  regulatory,  policy,  and  institutional  framework, 
diversifying formal financial instruments, easing barriers to trade and competitiveness, increasing 
digitalization, and aligning skills development with market needs—are aimed at creating a more 
cost-effective and efficient operating and commercial environment for SMEs. In parallel with 
countercyclical measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19), key structural reforms have continued with a prudent overall macroeconomic stance. The 
program is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Uzbekistan, 2021–2023 and 
is aligned with relevant ADB strategies and programs including Strategy 2030 (para. 14).  
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  The Government of Uzbekistan is accelerating its transition toward a market economy with 
the adoption of the National Action Strategy on Five Priority Development Areas (Strategy 2017–
2021) and follow-on Roadmap of Reforms.1 The contribution of SMEs to Uzbekistan’s gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth and formal and informal employment has been substantial. The 
government is keen to build on these gains and make SMEs even more integral to its policy 
objectives of diversifying the economy, creating value-added employment, reducing the informal 
economy, and creating effective links with regional and global value chains. Pillar 3.4 of Strategy 
2017–2021 is focused on institutional and structural reforms to reduce the state’s presence in the 
economy and create a favorable environment for small businesses and private entrepreneurship. 
 
4.  COVID-19  impact  and  macroeconomic  policy  management.  COVID-19  severely 
impacted Uzbekistan’s economy in the early part of 2020, but the impact was moderated by timely 
containment and support measures. GDP growth, which averaged 6.8% during 2010–2019, 
slowed to 1.6%—well below the pre-COVID-19 forecast of 6%.2 Economic recessions in its main 
trading partners led to a 17% decline in imports from Kazakhstan in 2020. However, gold exports 
surged by 18%. Travel restrictions impacted migrant workers working in the Russian Federation

5.  Contribution  of  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  to  economic  growth  and 
poverty reduction. Uzbekistan’s economic expansion during 2010–2019 has been concomitant 
with the rising incomes of SMEs and microenterprises, regular minimum wage increases, and 
improved social safety nets to cushion the impacts of structural reforms that have been underway 
since 2017. The national poverty rate declined from 25.8% in 2005 to 11% in 2019. Supported by 
government policies to develop the private sector and improve the country’s business climate, the 
role  of  SMEs  in  the  economy  has  become  significant,  particularly  in  terms  of  providing 
employment.5 About 411,203 SMEs were registered and active at the end of 2020, up 4% year-
on-year. SMEs accounted for 54% of GDP in 2019–2020, with sectoral breakdown being 97% in 
agriculture, 82% in trade, 72% in construction, and 52% in services. SMEs accounted for 27% of 
exports  and  62%  of  imports.  Their  share  of  investment  was  40%.6 SMEs  are  the  largest 
employers, providing 78% of formal and informal jobs combined in 2018, compared with 50% in 
2000.7 In 2020, of SUM48.4 trillion in credit extended to small businesses, SUM6.1 trillion was 
channeled through the Family Entrepreneurship Development Program to provide low-cost credit 
to spur regional micro-entrepreneurship.8 SMEs are critical for achieving and sustaining the 
growth forecast of above 5% annually for the 2021–2024 period and for boosting employment. 
 
6.  COVID-19  impact  on  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  government 
response. In Uzbekistan, the economic shock triggered by COVID-19 affected SMEs through lost 
sales and revenues and depleted cash reserves. Tourism, hospitality, catering, and transport 
experienced the sharpest drop in demand and revenue, leading to suspension of operations, 
frequent involuntary leaves (especially unpaid), layoffs, and salary cuts (for those who remained 
employed). Tourism, a key SME segment, saw only 1.5 million international arrivals in 2020—a 
77% decline compared with 2019.9 Women, comprising 54% of workers in catering and trade 
SMEs, and 46% of workers in agriculture and forestry, have been substantially affected. In

7.  Reforms  to  support  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  continuing 
constraints. Since 2017, Uzbekistan has been undertaking reforms to improve the enabling 
environment for private sector development, including SMEs. Commencing in January 2019, tax 
system distortions that unfairly burdened small businesses were removed. Tax rates for personal 
income, corporate income, and payroll were unified for both large and small firms. Tax rates for 
small firms were reduced (unified tax rate from 5% to 4%, property tax rate from 5% to 2%, and 
dividend tax from 10% to 5%). Tax policy and administration reforms have resulted in 30,000 new 
firms  entering  the  standard  tax  regime  and  boosting  tax  revenue  in  2019.11 To  support 
entrepreneurship, the value-added tax rate was reduced from 20% to 15% in October 2019.12 To 
ease  cross-border  trade,  risk-based  inspections  have  been  instituted  and  documentation 
requirements for imports simplified. To reduce SMEs’ transport costs, since May 2019 exporters 
have been compensated by the Government up to 50% of their rail transport costs, and from 
February 2020 this has also applied to road and air transport.13 Strategy 2017–2021 and related 
decrees have identified reform areas to facilitate SME development and increase the resilience 
of SMEs to future shocks in the context of the overall thrust to diversify the economy and drive 
growth through the private sector.14 The program will help the government identify and implement 
key actions within those reforms areas.15 
 
8.  Lack of diversified financing instruments. SMEs in Uzbekistan lack access to the 
diversified formal financial instruments needed for various phases of the SME life cycle. Although 
most widely used, bank finance is marked by high interest rates (about 19%), and only about one-
quarter of SMEs have a bank loan. More than 80% of SMEs finance their working capital and 
investment needs through internally generated funds or personal sources. Banks see SMEs as a 
high credit risk and have limited expertise in evaluating SME loans. Coupled with difficulties in 
enforcing creditors' rights, this higher risk perception translates into high collateral requirements 
(despite  sufficient  cash  flow  or  purchase  orders)  and  complex  application  procedures, 
disproportionately affecting women’s businesses. Data from the Collateral Registry indicate that 
about 94% of loans issued since 2015 have been secured by hard collateral while 4% have been 
secured by cash deposits. Despite a 25% expansion in access to bank credit, the share of loans 
to women’s small businesses shrank from 11.6% in 2018 to 8.1% in 2019 (the share of all loans

9.  Low  financial  literacy  of  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises.  Most  SMEs  in 
Uzbekistan have low financial literacy, adversely impacting sound business decisions and long-
term sustainability. Credible business plans and appropriate financial reporting  are lacking. 
Training in bookkeeping and financial statement and cash-flow analysis is critical for SMEs to take 
advantage of risk-assessed business opportunities and minimize information gaps to access 
appropriate sources of finance. The Central Bank of Uzbekistan (CBU) is implementing programs 
to improve the financial literacy of the population and increase uptake of digital financial services. 
 
10.  High institutional and administrative costs. The government has simplified some 
business-related legislation, streamlined business registration and tax payment procedures, and 
expanded e-government services (para. 7). However, institutional and administrative burdens 
continue to impose costs on doing business for SMEs. Obtaining permits and licenses, including 
construction permits, is costlier for small firms than for large firms.21 It can take up to 246 days to 
obtain a construction permit, compared with an average of 170 days in other Central Asian 
countries. Most SMEs remain microentrepreneurs, operating in low-value-added sectors, and are 
 
not registered (footnote 5). Reducing the number of permits and licenses required by 30% could 
save SMEs at least SUM125 billion a year, while digitalization using a single e-portal system 
would save at least SUM13 billion in printing costs and make the registration process more 
efficient and expedient.22 A single point of contact would prevent overlapping of government 
agencies' services, including credit lines, training, and advisory services. In the absence of an 
SME definition consistent with international best practices, financial and non-financial support 
targeted towards SMEs will be ineffective and inefficient.

11.  Low human capital development, including entrepreneurial skills. With almost 60% 
of the population of Uzbekistan under the age of 30 and with the country's economic structure in 
transition from labor-intensive agriculture to services and industry (including technology-focused

and training (TVET) needs to be aligned with the needs of the labor market to increase the 
competitiveness of businesses. TVET in Uzbekistan largely lacks industry involvement in the 
articulation of skills demand, development of competency standards and curricula, delivery of 
training, and assessment and certification. Teachers and masters need to update their knowledge 
and experience related to the industry practices and the TVET institutions are often lacking 
updated training equipment and facilities. Enterprise surveys, and occupational demand and 
supply outlooks to better guide TVET, are also lacking. Labor market information systems are still 
at the initial stage of development, hindering the job search and skills signaling process. Skills 
shortages  are  prevalent  in  construction,  transport,  and  information  and  communications 
technology (ICT)—the key growth sectors of the economy among others.23 Skilled human capital 
will  be  critical  to  increasing  enterprise  productivity,  creating  higher-value-added  jobs,  and 
reducing regional inequalities.24 Industry–skills consultative bodies (e.g., sector skills councils) 
are  being  established  under  the  government’s  very  recent  reform  request.    Quality  sex-
disaggregated data will help address the institutional, financial, and legal barriers to training 
women entrepreneurs. Labor market information systems are needed to better link job seekers 
with employers and ensure that newly acquired skills translate into employment and productivity. 
Skills development in the country requires coordination among  various government and sectoral 
players, including the private sector,  to link TVET and training programs to market needs.25 A 
dedicated skills development window under the State Unemployment Fund would also be a useful 
platform to support this coordination.  
 
12.  Underexploited benefits of digitalization. Digitalization tools, services, and practices 
help overcome the size-related barriers that SMEs typically face in innovating, growing, linking to 
global value chains, and ultimately becoming more productive and competitive. Because most 
SMEs in Uzbekistan are unaware of the range of digital possibilities open to them, their digital 
uptake is largely confined to basic services—e.g., a website, or use of social media for business 
purposes. Most SMEs lack the skills to identify technology and financing solutions to help them 
grow.  The  COVID-19  outbreak  has  shown  how  digitalization  can  be leveraged to  develop 
innovative  and  more  resilient  business  models.  Digitalization  has  the  potential  to  reduce 
transaction costs and lower entry barriers for SMEs and microenterprises.26 Training programs 
for  SMEs  on  the  use  of  digital  technology  for  business  development  complemented  by 
government-funded  high-speed  telecommunication  infrastructure  will  promote  SME

respect to cybersecurity and data protection. Financial technology (fintech) regulatory sandboxes

13.  Weak trade facilitation infrastructure. As a double landlocked country, Uzbekistan is 
handicapped by the policies and infrastructure of its neighbors.28The time and monetary costs for

of Central Asia.29 The Export Promotion Agency provides information on consumer preferences,

viable sales and marketing plans or facilitate transactions. The national system of technical

14.  The program supports private sector-led diversified economic growth, with SMEs and 
entrepreneurship at the forefront (para. 1), and is in line with ADB’s country operations business 
plan for Uzbekistan, 2021–2023 and country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan, 2019–2023.30 It

B.  Policy Reform, ADB’s Value Addition, and Sustainability 
 
15.  Programmatic approach. Given that improving the SME enabling environment requires 
time-bound reforms in parallel across sectors, the two-subprogram programmatic approach is 
most suited for the program. The approach (i) facilitates effective coordination among multiple 
agencies to ensure that subprograms 1 and 2, individually and collectively, achieve meaningful 
improvements through well-deliberated and government-driven reforms; (ii) where warranted, 
allows follow-up reforms under subprogram 2 as well as continued implementation of reforms 
started in subprogram 1; (iii) allows time to build the institutional capacity of key agencies, 
particularly the Entrepreneurship Development Agency (EDA) and the State Fund (which has 
been  revamped  in  2021)  to  help  them  become  effective  host  institutions  for  future  SME

C.  Expected Outcome of the Reforms 
 
23.  The program is aligned with the country’s overarching development objective of increased 
employment (footnote 1). The expected outcome is the enabling environment for SME growth, 
diversification,  and  high-value-added  job  creation  improved.  The  links  between  the  reform 
proposals and the outcome can be illustrated as follows: (i) for reform area 1, diversifying the 
range of financial instruments will help expand the operations of more than 185,000 credit-
constrained SMEs; (ii) for reform area 2, reducing the number of permits and licenses that SMEs 
need to obtain from the government and streamlining SME support services will improve the 
viability of small businesses by saving nearly SUM125 billion per year in unwarranted operational 
costs, and will also incentivize formalization (i.e., registration); (iii) for reform area 3, accrediting 
testing laboratories internationally, harmonizing outdated technical regulations and standards with 
international norms, and effectively utilizing the EU’s GSP+ trade status will increase SME exports

trainees and professionals, attending professional training centers and digital competency training 
centers  for  value-added  private  sector  SME  jobs  per  year,  including  women  and  women 
entrepreneurs. Overall, the program i.e., subprogram 1, will increase SMEs’ share in GDP by $30 
million and create nearly 13,700 jobs in 2021. 38
